Cross posting from <#C300Z3U49|civic-tech> This article is a really interesting explanation of the subconscious divisions between globalist and nationalists. <http://www.the-american-interest.com/2016/07/10/when-and-why-nationalism-beats-globalism/>
Highly recommended read

the TL'DR is that as globalists, you believe that no one persons life is worth more than anthers, no matters where they live. In fact, valuing the life of one person, who lives within an arbitrary line most likely drawn up by geography or colonialists, over the life of another is very close to racism,

While nationalists see patriotism as a virtue; they think their country and its culture are unique and worth preserving. Nationalists feel a bond with their country, and they believe that this bond imposes moral obligations both ways: Citizens have a duty to love and serve their country, and governments are duty bound to protect their own people. Governments should place their citizens interests above the interests of people in other countries.
I wish there was a way of explaining this to my conservative Ann Coulter-loving relatives in a calm way.

Immigration, one of the top issues of Western elections, hits at the heart of this anxiety. In Europe, By the summer of 2015 the nationalist side was already at the boiling point, shouting ‚Äúenough is enough, close the tap,‚Äù when the globalists proclaimed, ‚Äúlet us open the floodgates, it‚Äôs the compassionate thing to do, and if you oppose us you are a racist.‚Äù
Anyways, it's a great essay. please read. <http://www.the-american-interest.com/2016/07/10/when-and-why-nationalism-beats-globalism/> :slightly_smiling_face:

Thing is, I feel that's where the US is potentially unique: the ideals of Nationalism and Globalism needn't be at odds. "Give me your tired, your poor, Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free." Being a country of immigrants, we are fundamentally of the world. Can we not be fiercely proud of our identity as the land of opportunity, see ourselves as unique, and thus live as an example to the rest of the world?
Can we be the "City on the Hill" not through protectionism, but through compassion?
Then again, easy for me to say, as the privileged, educated, white male who isn't seeing his opportunities being bled dry by globalization
looking forward to the read <@U0B9N0HF0>
It's almost even more than just globalist vs. nationalist, but individualist vs. tribe. From the article:

_ountries seem to move in two directions, along two axes: first, as they industrialize, they move away from ‚Äútraditional values‚Äù in which religion, ritual, and deference to authorities are important, and toward ‚Äúsecular rational‚Äù values that are more open to change, progress, and social engineering based on rational considerations. Second, as they grow wealthier and more citizens move into the service sector, nations move away from ‚Äúsurvival values‚Äù emphasizing the economic and physical security found in one‚Äôs family, tribe, and other parochial groups, toward ‚Äúself-expression‚Äù or ‚Äúemancipative values‚Äù that emphasize individual rights and protections‚Äînot just for oneself, but as a matter of principle, for everyone._
